Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54424-002 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
June 2021 
 
 
 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan:  Preparing the Micro, 
Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises Financial 
Access, Inclusivity, and Resilience Project  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document to the public in accordance with ADB's 
Access to Information Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 17 June 2021) 
 
Currency unit  –  Pakistan rupee/s (PRe/PRs) 
PRe 1.00  =  $ 0.0063822196     
$1.00  =  PRs 156.685300     
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  KJP  –  Kamyab Jawan Program 
  MFB  –  microfinance banks 
  MFI  –  microfinance institutions 
  MFP  –  microfinance providers 
  MSE  –  micro and small-sized Enterprises 
  MSME  –  micro, small and medium-sized enterprises 
  PMIC  –  Pakistan Microfinance Investment Company 
  PMN  –  Pakistan Microfinance Network 
  SBP  –  State Bank of Pakistan 
  SECP  –  Securities and Exchange Commission 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  YES  –  Youth Entrepreneurship Scheme 
 
NOTE{S} 
 
(i)  In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Eugenue Zhukov, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD)

CONTENTS 
Page 
TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT  2 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  3 
A.  Justification  3 
B.  Outputs and Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  6 
APPENDIXES 
1. Cost Estimates And Financing Plan  7 
2. List of Linked Documents  8

2   
 
 
  
I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  Pakistan economic growth is significantly hindered by the low growth of its micro, small 
and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs). A key constraint to the development of the MSME sector 
is the limited access to finance. Commercial bank credit to gross domestic product (GDP) has 
plummeted from 29% in 2008 to 18% of GDP in 2019. Of private credit to GDP, the MSME sector 
is among the least serviced.1 Although MSMEs constitute more than 30% of the GDP and 80% 
of non-agricultural employment, these enterprises are a significantly smaller part of the GDP as 
compared to other peer countries. 23 
 
2.  The microfinance sector is the primary financier, in terms of number of borrowers, for 
MSMEs. Pakistan’s formal financial system provides financing for 7.2 million MSMEs. The 
significant majority of these (7.0 million) are serviced by microfinance providers (MFPs), including 
6.7 million households and 263,000 micro and small-sized enterprise (MSE).4 
 
3.  Deep impact of COVID-19 on MSMEs. By the end of 2020, Pakistan’s microfinance 
industry had outstanding loans of approximately $2.0 billion (PRs 324 billion).5 Since 2015 the 
MSE loan book has grown at a compound average growth rate of 35% while client outreach 
increased at a compound average growth rate of 20%. However, due to the economic decline in 
2019 and the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, client outreach and loan disbursements 
to  households  dropped  sharply  and  further  decline  is  anticipated. Women  borrowers  were 
particularly hard hit. The proposed project is to restore economic resilience of the household and 
MSME borrowers in response to the ongoing crisis and help kick-start lending to this clientele.  
 
4.  In 2018 the Government published targets to be met by 2023 under the National Financial 
Inclusion Strategy (NFIS) to support financial access and inclusion, and eventually economic 
growth. The Strategy encompassed five major targets, including enhancing access to finance for 
small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and increasing agriculture finance, including to rural areas. 
With an expected $200 million gap in liquidity for the microfinance sector due to the coronavirus 
pandemic and the 2019 economic slowdown, access to finance for MSMEs is expected to suffer 
further. Resultingly, the Government requested ADB to support MSMEs through the microfinance 
sector.  
 
5.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help preparation of a proposed loan of $125 
million  from  ADBs  ordinary capital resources supporting  financial  inclusion  of MSMEs  and 
entrepreneurial households in Pakistan. The proposed project will be aligned to the following 
impact:  women  and  rural  beneficiaries  enhanced  and  economic  resilience  of  MSEs  and 
households,  in  response  to  economic  decline  and  COVID-19,  supported.  The  outcome  is 
increased MSE and household financial services outreach with a special focus on women and 
rural areas. The project will have three outputs: (i) risk taking capacity of microfinance providers 
expanded, (ii) funding of selected microfinance providers enhanced, and (iii) Government’s Youth 
Entrepreneurship Scheme program outreach enhanced. 
 
1  World Bank. Global Findex Database. http://www. https://globalfindex.worldbank.org/ (accessed 15 October 2019). 
2  Small and Medium Enterprise Development Authority. 2020. State of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs)in 
Pakistan. Lahore. 
3  Edinburgh Group. 2013. Growing the global economy through SMEs. http://www.edinburgh-
group.org/media/2776/edinburgh_group_research_-_growing_the_global_economy_through_smes.pdf 
4 Pakistan Microfinance Network. 2021. Microwatch Issue 58 Q4 2020. Islamabad. 
5 Pakistan Microfinance Network. 2021. Microwatch Issue 56 Q2 2020. Islamabad.

3 
 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
6.  The transaction technical assistance (TRTA) will help the ADB project team, and the 
government prepare the project. The TRTA is justified given the innovative financing mechanisms 
to be employed under the project. ADB has been a key development partner in the microfinance 
sector for Pakistan, however this will be the first project in the sector since 2006. technical 
assistance (TA) will develop the project design and has five outputs: (i) Wholesale administrator 
of funds confirmed, (ii) MFPs selected, (iii) Credit guarantee facility designed, (iv) Credit auction 
system designed and managed, and (v) Capacity of Government support for MSMEs, including 
YES Program, improved. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
7.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) supports the project design described in the 
concept paper as follows: 
 
8.  Output  1:  Wholesale  distributor  of  funds  confirmed.  The  Pakistan  Microfinance 
Investment Company (PMIC) is the anticipated wholesale administrator of the credit guarantee 
facility (Project Output 1) and loan facility (Project Output 2).6 The TA will support the project team 
to: 
 
(i)  Conduct due diligence on PMIC to confirm commitment and capability in selecting 
eligible microfinance providers (MFPs), including microfinance banks (MFBs) and 
microfinance institutions (MFIs), and originating and managing guarantees for them; 
(ii)  Conduct due diligence on PMIC to confirm commitment and capability in selecting 
eligible MFPs, and managing loans to MFPs; 
(iii)  Subject to confirmation of the due diligence findings by the government and the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), prepare documentation, including a draft term 
sheets, loan and project agreements setting out key performance criteria, covenants, 
administration arrangements related to PMIC’s duties for reflection in the project 
administration manual (PAM) and other project agreements.7 
 
9.  Output  2:  Microfinance  providers  selected.  To  ensure  financial  and  managerial 
soundness and ability of MFPs to absorb credit guarantees and additional credit, the TA will 
support the project team to identify suitable MFPs participating in the project. This includes a 
review of MFP outreach practices to priority sectors and identification of TA measures to improve 
women client outreach via branchless banking solutions and women targeted financial literacy 
training during project implementation. 
 
10.  This entails the preparation of a list of MFPs based on eligibility criteria including their 
financial track record, absorptive capacity, target beneficiary focus in MSE, women, and rural 
 
6 PMIC is a national apex institution for microfinance providers in the country. PMIC provides market-based wholesale 
lending (debt and equity) to microfinance providers that on-lend to borrowers. PMIC was established as a pillar of 
the Government of Pakistan’s National Financial Inclusion Strategy. The shareholders of PMIC include Pakistan 
Poverty  Alleviation  Fund  (Government  of  Pakistan),  Karandaaz  Pakistan  (UK  Foreign,  Commonwealth  and 
Development Office supported) and KfW. 
7 Should PMIC not be considered suitable, the TA will identify alternative arrangements in coordination with the 
regulators (State Bank of Pakistan and the Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan).

4   
 
market segments, as well as use of branchless banking technology.8 The TA will support the 
project team to conduct due diligence on selected MFPs, anticipated to be done in close 
coordination with PMIC.  
 
11.  Due diligence will confirm the MFP funding requirements, in particular the need for pari 
passu guarantees, senior debt and subordinated debt based on which ADB loan funds will be 
allocated.9 Since MFBs have access to significant deposit funds it appears that guarantees or 
subordinated debt instruments are needed to fund MFB growth, while MFIs likely need senior 
loans to boost liquidity, and in some cases subordinated loans to strengthen their solvency.  
 
12.  Subsequent to confirmation of the wholesale administrator of funds (preferably PMIC) and 
the selection of MFPs, the TA will support the project team in completing project documentation 
including  financial  analysis,  financial  management  assessment,  environmental  and  social 
safeguard arrangements, and integrity due diligence of the executing agencies, implementing 
agencies, and selected MFPs; and preparation of a gender action plan consistent with national 
law and applicable ADB policies. 
 
13.  Output 3: Credit guarantee facility designed. Pari passu credit guarantees covering up 
to 50% of eligible loans (Project Output 1) are expected to boost lending to priority sectors (women 
and rural beneficiaries). The credit guarantees to be distributed and managed by an administrator 
(PMIC) will be backed by an ADB stand-by loan to the government. The TA will:  
   
(i)  identify MFPs’ target beneficiary segments within defined exposure limits; 
(ii)  propose key performance indicators for monitoring participating MFPs (identified 
under TA Output 2) and subloan utilization by target beneficiaries, especially women 
and rural borrowers;  
(iii)  draft guarantee underwriting, selection, and monitoring guidelines; 
(iv)  draft guarantee pricing and loss adjustment policies and procedures; 
(v)  draft model guarantee term sheet and risk participation agreement; 
(vi)  draft disbursement arrangements and related reporting requirements; and  
(vii)  draft  guarantee  agreements  setting  out  key  performance  criteria,  covenants, 
administration arrangements for reflection in the PAM and project agreements. 
 
14.  Output 4: Credit auction system designed and managed. To address MFP short term 
funding needs and to strengthen solvency, an ADB loan will offer senior and subordinated loans 
to selected MFPs. The senior loans will carry maturities of up to 36 months and subordinated 
loans will carry maturities of up to 10 years. The maturity of the ADB loan will not exceed 10 years 
permitting up to four funding rounds for senior loans to MFPs. The loan funds will be distributed 
through an auction process administered by a reputable international consulting firm, acting as 
an independent third party. The TA will support the project by drafting:  
(i)  contractual arrangements of ADB and PMIC with the government for channeling the 
loan;  
(ii)  an independent auctioning process to ensure efficiency, transparency, and fairness;  
(iii)  estimate cost for administering the auctions and the auctioning process as described 
in the terms of reference for the independent third party; 
 
8 Shortlisting Criteria for Microfinance Providers (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
9 An initial survey of the active MFPs revealed a high demand for the facilities offered under the proposed project. The 
interested MFPs constitute a significant majority of the sub-borrower base and include some of the largest MFPs. At 
least six MFBs and nine MFIs expressed interest in the guarantee and/or credit enhancement facilities. During the 
project processing phase, there will be further clarity on the number of eligible MFPs under the project.

5 
 
(iv)  operating rules for the auction mechanism including a dedicated auction website to 
ensure timely disclosure of auction results, and loan disbursements by participating 
MFPs; 
(v)  a competitive price setting mechanism for the auctioning process; 
(vi)  eligibility criteria and borrowing limits for MFPs reflecting their financial standing, 
absorptive capacity based on TA Output 1 and funding needs for target beneficiaries; 
(vii)  model senior and subordinated term sheets and related loan agreements, including 
setting out key performance criteria, and covenants; 
(viii)  disbursement arrangements and related reporting requirements;  
(ix)  key performance criteria, covenants, administration arrangements for reflection in 
the PAM and project agreements; and 
(x)  standard operating procedures for the auctioning including announcing, execution 
and reporting of auction results to the Project Steering Committee and subsequently 
publishing approved results on a website. 
(xi)  the tasks of the administrator (PMIC) in executing the loan agreements with MFPs. 
 
15.  Output 5. Capacity of government support for MSMEs, including YES Program, 
improved.  At  request  of  the  government,  ADB  will  support  the  government’s  Youth 
Entrepreneurship Scheme (YES) Phase 2 targeting MSEs with loans up to PRs1 million ($6,190) 
under Project Output 3. The TA will:  
 
(i)  review YES Phase 1 as well as the design for Phase 2 and identify gaps for 
improvement; 
(ii)  review the government’s strategic objectives and lessons from past programs;  
(iii)  review YES credit and guarantee underwriting processes, exposure and risk limits, 
recommend improvements on the quality of investments, and widen access to 
eligible beneficiaries; 
(iv)  if ADB is satisfied with the design of the YES, support the project team in completion 
of proposed Project Output 3 project documentation, draft key performance criteria, 
covenants, administration arrangements for reflection in the PAM and other project 
agreements. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and (ii) $500,000 will 
be financed on grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and 
administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. Funding from the 
Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund will support Outputs 3 and 4 of the 
TA  and  knowledge  sharing  events.10 The  government  will  bear  the costs related to  office 
accommodation and in-kind support by dedicated executing and implementing agency staff as 
well as in relation to project coordination. The government was informed that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.   
                 
 
 
 
10  The EAKPF will finance operational expenses related to eligible proposals, as agreed upon by the Government and 
ADB. It will not be used for  (i) civil works, (ii) procurement of large-scale equipment, (iii) permanent staffing costs, or 
(iv) the hiring of staff consultants.

6   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA through the Pakistan Resident Mission of its Central and West 
Asia Department, which will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize discussions; 
and provide staff to act as resource persons, as required. Implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table below. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  June 2021-December 2027 
Executing agency  ADB Pakistan Resident Mission 
Implementing agencies  ADB Pakistan Resident Mission 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Firm: (QCBS), 90:10  OCB, International (28  $377,000 
  person-months of which 4 PM 
for the team leader 
Individual Selection  International and national  $543,000 
Method  experts (58.5 person-months) 
 
Disbursement  Disbursement of TA resources will follow ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
Disbursement arrangement: ADBs TASF will fund Output 1, 2, and 5. 
EAKPF will provide funding for Outputs 3 and 4, as well as for 
knowledge sharing events. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank; OCB= open competitive bidding, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a firm and individual consultants following the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration  instructions  and/or  staff  instructions.11 The  total  estimated  level  of  effort  for 
consulting services is 86.5 person-months consisting of 11 person-months of international and 
75.5 person-months of national consulting inputs.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

Appendix 1  7
